author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.pli: Aṅguttara Nikāya 5
segments.en: Numbered Discourses 5

segments.pli: 14. Rājavagga
segments.en: 14. Kings

segments.pli: 139. Akkhamasutta
segments.en: 139. Cannot Endure

segments.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo na rājāraho hoti na rājabhoggo, na rañño aṅgaṃtveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors is not worthy of a king, not fit to serve a king, and is not considered a factor of kingship.

segments.pli: Katamehi pañcahi?
segments.en: What five?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthikāyaṃ vā disvā assakāyaṃ vā disvā rathakāyaṃ vā disvā pattikāyaṃ vā disvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders at the sight of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ. (1)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure sights.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure sounds?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthisaddaṃ vā sutvā assasaddaṃ vā sutvā rathasaddaṃ vā sutvā pattisaddaṃ vā sutvā bheripaṇavasaṅkhatiṇavaninnādasaddaṃ vā sutvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders at the sound of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry, or the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ. (2)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure sounds.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure smells?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ye te rañño nāgā abhijātā saṅgāmāvacarā tesaṃ muttakarīsassa gandhaṃ ghāyitvā saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when it smells the odor of the feces and urine of battle-hardened, pedigree royal bull elephants. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ. (3)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure smells.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure tastes?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ekissā vā tiṇodakadattiyā vimānito dvīhi vā tīhi vā catūhi vā pañcahi vā tiṇodakadattīhi vimānito saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when it misses a meal of grass and water, or it misses two, three, four, or five meals. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ. (4)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure tastes.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can’t endure touches?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ekena vā saravegena viddho, dvīhi vā tīhi vā catūhi vā pañcahi vā saravegehi viddho saṃsīdati visīdati, na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle falters and founders when struck by a swift arrow, or by two, three, four, or five swift arrows. It doesn’t stay firm, and fails to plunge into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo akkhamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ. (5)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can’t endure touches.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo na rājāraho hoti na rājabhoggo na rañño aṅgaṃtveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: A royal bull elephant with these five factors is not worthy of a king, not fit to serve a king, and is not considered a factor of kingship.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu na āhuneyyo hoti na pāhuneyyo na dakkhiṇeyyo na añjalikaraṇīyo na anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
segments.en: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities is not worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, not worthy of hospitality, not worthy of a religious donation, not worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is not the supreme field of merit for the world.

segments.pli: Katamehi pañcahi?
segments.en: What five?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ, akkhamo saddānaṃ, akkhamo gandhānaṃ, akkhamo rasānaṃ, akkhamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant can’t endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure sights?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rajanīye rūpe sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is aroused by a desirable sight, so is not able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rūpānaṃ. (1)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure sights.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure sounds?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sotena saddaṃ sutvā rajanīye sadde sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, hearing a sound with their ears, is aroused by a desirable sound, so is not able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti saddānaṃ. (2)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure sounds.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure smells?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā rajanīye gandhe sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, smelling an odor with their nose, is aroused by a desirable smell, so is not able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti gandhānaṃ. (3)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure smells.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure tastes?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā rajanīye rase sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, tasting a flavor with their tongue, is aroused by desirable tastes, so is not able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti rasānaṃ. (4)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure tastes.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can’t endure touches?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā rajanīye phoṭṭhabbe sārajjati, na sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, feeling a touch with their body, is aroused by a desirable touch, so is not able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ. (5)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can’t endure touches.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu na āhuneyyo hoti na pāhuneyyo na dakkhiṇeyyo na añjalikaraṇīyo na anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
segments.en: A mendicant with these five qualities is not worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, not worthy of hospitality, not worthy of a religious donation, not worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is not the supreme field of merit for the world.

segments.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅgaṃtveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: A royal bull elephant with five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.

segments.pli: Katamehi pañcahi?
segments.en: What five?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti rūpānaṃ, khamo saddānaṃ, khamo gandhānaṃ, khamo rasānaṃ, khamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant can endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti rūpānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure sights?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthikāyaṃ vā disvā assakāyaṃ vā disvā rathakāyaṃ vā disvā pattikāyaṃ vā disvā na saṃsīdati na visīdati, santhambhati sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder at the sight of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti rūpānaṃ. (1)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure sights.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti saddānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure sounds?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato hatthisaddaṃ vā sutvā assasaddaṃ vā sutvā rathasaddaṃ vā sutvā pattisaddaṃ vā sutvā bheripaṇavasaṅkhatiṇavaninnādasaddaṃ vā sutvā na saṃsīdati na visīdati, santhambhati sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant does not falter or founder at the sound of a division of elephants, of cavalry, of chariots, or of infantry, or the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti saddānaṃ. (2)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure sounds.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti gandhānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure smells?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ye te rañño nāgā abhijātā saṅgāmāvacarā tesaṃ muttakarīsassa gandhaṃ ghāyitvā na saṃsīdati na visīdati, santhambhati sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder when it smells the odor of the feces and urine of battle-hardened, pedigree royal bull elephants. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti gandhānaṃ. (3)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure smells.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti rasānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure tastes?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ekissā vā tiṇodakadattiyā vimānito dvīhi vā tīhi vā catūhi vā pañcahi vā tiṇodakadattīhi vimānito na saṃsīdati na visīdati, santhambhati sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder when it misses a meal of grass and water, or it misses two, three, four, or five meals. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti rasānaṃ. (4)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure tastes.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a royal bull elephant can endure touches?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo saṅgāmagato ekena vā saravegena viddho, dvīhi vā tīhi vā catūhi vā pañcahi vā saravegehi viddho na saṃsīdati na visīdati, santhambhati sakkoti saṅgāmaṃ otarituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a royal bull elephant gone to battle does not falter or founder when struck by a swift arrow, or by two, three, four, or five swift arrows. It stays firm, and plunges into battle.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, rañño nāgo khamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ. (5)
segments.en: That’s how a royal bull elephant can endure touches.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño nāgo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅgaṃtveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: A royal bull elephant with these five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.

segments.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
segments.en: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

segments.pli: Katamehi pañcahi?
segments.en: What five?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti rūpānaṃ, khamo saddānaṃ, khamo gandhānaṃ, khamo rasānaṃ, khamo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant can endure sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti rūpānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can endure sights?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā rajanīye rūpe na sārajjati, sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is not aroused by a desirable sight, so is able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti rūpānaṃ. (1)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can endure sights.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti saddānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can endure sounds?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sotena saddaṃ sutvā rajanīye sadde na sārajjati, sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, hearing a sound with their ears, is not aroused by desirable sounds, so is able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti saddānaṃ. (2)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can endure sounds.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti gandhānaṃ.
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can endure smells?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā rajanīye gandhe na sārajjati, sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, smelling an odor with their nose, is not aroused by a desirable smell, so is able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti gandhānaṃ. (3)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can endure smells.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti rasānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can endure tastes?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā rajanīye rase na sārajjati, sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, tasting a flavor with their tongue, is not aroused by desirable tastes, so is able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti rasānaṃ. (4)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can endure tastes.

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ?
segments.en: And how is it that a mendicant can endure touches?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā rajanīye phoṭṭhabbe na sārajjati, sakkoti cittaṃ samādahituṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant, feeling a touch with their body, is not aroused by a desirable touch, so is able to still the mind.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khamo hoti phoṭṭhabbānaṃ. (5)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant can endure touches.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
segments.en: A mendicant with these five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

segments.pli: Navamaṃ.

sections.title: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors is…
